column7:
'>distraught
adjective
/dɪˈstrɔːt/|extremely upset and anxious so that you cannot think clearly
column8:
'>Examples:
- She’s still too distraught to speak about the tragedy.
- The child’s distraught parents pleaded for witnesses to contact the police.

column7:
'>triumphalist
adjective
/traɪˈʌmfəlɪst/|celebrating a victory or success in a way that is too proud and is intended to upset the people you have defeated
column8:
'>Examples:
- He warned that a triumphalist parade would be insensitive to the local people.

column7:
'>suffragist
noun
/ˈsʌfrədʒɪst/|a person who campaigns for a group of people who do not have the right to vote in elections, in order to get this right for them
column8:
'>Examples:
- She was a committed socialist, suffragist and feminist.

column7:
'>abolitionist
noun
/ˌæbəˈlɪʃənɪst/|a person who is in favour of the abolition of something, especially capital punishment (= punishment by death) or (in the past) slavery
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>hail
verb
/heɪl/|to describe somebody/something as being very good or special, especially in newspapers, etc.
column8:
'>Examples:
- (be hailed (as) something) The conference was hailed as a great success.
- The expedition was widely hailed as a success.
- Teenager Matt Brown is being hailed a hero for saving a young child from drowning.
- (hail somebody/something as something) Union leaders hailed the socialists’ victory as a huge step forward.

column7:
'>hail
verb
/heɪl/|(hail something) to signal to a taxi or a bus, in order to get the driver to stop
column8:
'>Examples:
- to hail a taxi/cab

column7:
'>hail
verb
/heɪl/|(hail somebody) to call to somebody in order to say hello to them or attract their attention
column8:
'>Examples:
- A voice hailed us from the other side of the street.
- We soon came within hailing distance of (= fairly close to) the others.

column7:
'>hail
verb
/heɪl/|when it hails, small balls of ice fall like rain from the sky
column8:
'>Examples:
- It's hailing!

column7:
'>hail
noun
/heɪl/|small balls of ice that fall like rain
column8:
'>Examples:
- We drove through hail and snow.

column7:
'>hail
noun
/heɪl/|(a hail of something) a large number or amount of something that is aimed at somebody in order to harm them
column8:
'>Examples:
- a hail of arrows/bullets
- a hail of abuse

column7:
'>anoint
verb
/əˈnɔɪnt/|(anoint somebody/something (with something)) to put oil or water on somebody’s head or body as part of a religious ceremony
column8:
'>Examples:
- The priest anointed her with oil.

column7:
'>caucus
noun
/ˈkɔːkəs/|a meeting of the members or leaders of a political party to choose candidates or to decide policy
column8: the members or leaders of a political party as a group
column9:
'>Examples:
- 20 states will hold precinct caucuses on Tuesday to choose delegates to the parties’ national conventions.

column7:
'>caucus
noun
/ˈkɔːkəs/|a group of people with similar interests, often within a larger organization or political party
column8:
'>Examples:
- the Congressional Black Caucus

column7:
'>caucus
verb
/ˈkɔːkəs/|to meet in a caucus or other group to discuss something
column8:
'>Examples:
- The senators decided to caucus about the policy change.

column7:
'>tumbleweed
noun
/ˈtʌmblwiːd/|a plant that grows like a bush in the desert areas of North America and Australia. In the autumn, it breaks off just above the ground and is blown around like a ball by the wind.
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>saloon
noun
/səˈluːn/|a car with a boot (= space at the back for carrying things) that is separated from the part where the driver and passengers sit
column8:
'>Examples:
- a five-seater family saloon
- a four-door saloon

column7:
'>saloon
noun
/səˈluːn/|a bar in a pub, hotel, etc. that is more comfortable than the other bars and where the drinks are usually more expensive
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>saloon
noun
/səˈluːn/|a bar where alcoholic drinks were sold in the western US and Canada in the past
column8:
'>Examples:
- The cowboy died in a fight in a saloon.
- There were sawdust-on-the-floor Western saloons with gunfights and poker games.

column7:
'>saloon
noun
/səˈluːn/|a large comfortable room on a ship, used by the passengers to sit and relax in
column8:
'>Examples:
- The saloon on deck B has room for 140 passengers.

column7:
'>behemoth
noun
/bɪˈhiːməθ/|something that is very big and powerful, especially a company or organization
column8:
'>Examples:
- a multinational corporate behemoth
- She works in a seventy-storey behemoth in Manhattan.

column7:
'>temperament
noun
/ˈtemprəmənt/|a person’s or an animal’s nature as shown in the way they behave or react to situations or people
column8:
'>Examples:
- to have an artistic temperament
- a horse with an excellent temperament
- She's a dreamer and a romantic by temperament.
- To become a champion, you have to have the right temperament.

column7:
'>temperament
noun
/ˈtemprəmənt/|the fact of tending to get emotional and excited very easily and behave in an unreasonable way
column8:
'>Examples:
- an actor given to displays of temperament

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a television station
column8:
'>Examples:
- a television/TV channel
- cable/digital/satellite channels
- a news channel
- a music/sports/movie channel
- to change/switch channels
- (on a channel) What's on Channel 4 tonight?

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a band of radio waves used for making television or radio broadcasts
column8:
'>Examples:
- radio channels
- terrestrial/satellite channels

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a method or system that people use to get information, to communicate, or to send something somewhere
column8:
'>Examples:
- Complaints must be made through the proper channels.
- The newsletter is a useful channel of communication between teacher and students.
- The company has worldwide distribution channels.
- Steps are being taken to implement a ceasefire through diplomatic channels.

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a means by which data is communicated and exchanged between elements of a computer system or other system
column8:
'>Examples:
- an audio channel

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a way of expressing ideas and feelings
column8:
'>Examples:
- The campaign provided a channel for protest against the war.
- Music is a great channel for releasing your emotions.

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a passage that water can flow along, especially in the ground, on the bottom of a river, etc.
column8:
'>Examples:
- drainage channels in the rice fields

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a deep passage of water in a river or near the coast that can be used as route for ships
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|a passage of water that connects two areas of water, especially two seas
column8:
'>Examples:
- the Bristol Channel

column7:
'>channel
noun
/ˈtʃænl/|the area of sea between England and France, also known as the English Channel
column8:
'>Examples:
- the Channel Tunnel
- cross-Channel ferries
- (across the Channel) news from across the Channel (= from France)

column7:
'>channel
verb
/ˈtʃænl/|(channel something (into something)) to direct money, feelings, ideas, etc. towards a particular thing or purpose
column8:
'>Examples:
- He channels his aggression into sport.

column7:
'>channel
verb
/ˈtʃænl/|(channel something (through something)) to send money, help, etc. using a particular route
column8:
'>Examples:
- Money for the project will be channelled through local government.

column7:
'>channel
verb
/ˈtʃænl/|(channel something) to carry or send water, light, etc. through a passage
column8:
'>Examples:
- A sensor channels the light signal along an optical fibre.

column7:
'>channel
verb
/ˈtʃænl/|(channel somebody) to act as a medium (= a person who claims to be able to communicate with the spirits of dead people) for somebody
column8:
'>Examples:
- He believed that he could channel an ancestor from two hundred years ago.

column7:
'>channel
verb
/ˈtʃænl/|(channel somebody) to behave in the manner of somebody else, as though that person has given you the idea or desire to act in that way
column8:
'>Examples:
- When he sang, he would channel Nat King Cole.

column7:
'>osteoporosis
noun
/ˌɑːstiəʊpəˈrəʊsɪs/|a condition in which the bones become weak and are easily broken, usually when people get older or because they do not eat enough of certain substances
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>homestead
noun
/ˈhəʊmsted/|a house with the land and buildings around it, especially a farm
column8:
'>Examples:
- What began as a small family homestead is now a 5 000-acre ranch.

column7:
'>homestead
noun
/ˈhəʊmsted/|(in the US in the past) a piece of land given to somebody by the government on condition that they lived on it and grew crops on it
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>homestead
verb
/ˈhəʊmsted/|to live and work on a homestead
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>bombast
noun
/ˈbɑːmbæst/|words which sound important but have little meaning, used to impress people
column8:
'>Examples:
- His speech was full of bombast.

column7:
'>prone
adjective
/prəʊn/|likely to suffer from something or to do something bad
column8:
'>Examples:
- (prone to something) prone to injury
- Working without a break makes you more prone to error.
- (prone to do something) Tired drivers were found to be particularly prone to ignore warning signs.
- (prone to doing something) people who are genetically prone to putting on weight

column7:
'>prone
adjective
/prəʊn/|likely to suffer or do the thing mentioned
column8:
'>Examples:
- error-prone
- injury-prone

column7:
'>prone
adjective
/prəʊn/|lying flat with the front of your body touching the ground
column8:
'>Examples:
- The victim lay prone without moving.
- He was found lying in a prone position.

column7:
'>lurid
adjective
/ˈlʊrɪd/|too bright in colour, in a way that is not attractive
column8:
'>Examples:
- She was wearing a lurid orange and green blouse.

column7:
'>lurid
adjective
/ˈlʊrɪd/|presented in a way that is intended to shock
column8:
'>Examples:
- lurid headlines
- The paper gave all the lurid details of the murder.

column7:
'>estranged
adjective
/ɪˈstreɪndʒd/|no longer living with your husband, wife or partner
column8:
'>Examples:
- his estranged wife Emma
- She is attempting to contact her estranged husband to break the news.
- He is being questioned in connection with the death of his estranged wife.
- She has been estranged from her husband since 1999.

column7:
'>estranged
adjective
/ɪˈstreɪndʒd/|(estranged (from somebody)) no longer friendly or in contact with somebody
column8:
'>Examples:
- He became estranged from his family after the argument.
- Formerly close friends, they had been estranged from each other for many years.

column7:
'>estranged
adjective
/ɪˈstreɪndʒd/|(estranged (from something)) no longer involved in or connected with something, especially something that used to be important to you
column8:
'>Examples:
- She felt estranged from her former existence.

column7:
'>cramped
adjective
/kræmpt/|a cramped room, etc. does not have enough space for the people in it
column8:
'>Examples:
- working in cramped conditions
- He lived for six months in a cold, cramped attic room.

column7:
'>cramped
adjective
/kræmpt/|not having room to move freely

'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>cramped
adjective
/kræmpt/|with small letters close together and therefore difficult to read
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

'>seismic
adjective
/ˈsaɪzmɪk/|connected with or caused by earthquakes
column8:
'>Examples:
- seismic waves

'>seismic
adjective
/ˈsaɪzmɪk/|having a very great effect
column8: of very great size
column9:
'>Examples:
- a seismic shift in the political process

column7:
'>imminent
adjective
/ˈɪmɪnənt/|likely to happen very soon
column8:
'>Examples:
- the imminent threat of invasion
- The system is in imminent danger of collapse.
- An announcement about his resignation is imminent.
- An attack seems imminent.

column7:
'>demise
noun
/dɪˈmaɪz/|the end or failure of an institution, an idea, a company, etc.
column8:
'>Examples:
- He praised the union's aims but predicted its early demise.
- the demise of the USSR

column7:
'>demise
noun
/dɪˈmaɪz/|death

'>Examples:
- his imminent/sudden/sad demise

'>gushing
adjective
/ˈɡʌʃɪŋ/|expressing so much enthusiasm, praise or emotion that it does not seem sincere
column8:
'>Examples:
- She gave an embarrassingly gushing acceptance speech.

'>contrarian
noun
/kənˈtreriən/|a person who opposes or rejects popular opinion, especially in financial markets
column8:
'>Examples:
- Contrarians warned that the stock markets' giant gains were not justified.

column7:
'>lone
adjective
/ləʊn/|without any other people or things
column8:
'>Examples:
- a lone sailor crossing the Atlantic
- The attack was carried out by a lone gunman in a crowded shopping centre.

column7:
'>lone
adjective
/ləʊn/|without a husband, wife or partner to share the care of children
column8:
'>Examples:
- a lone mother/parent/father
- Most lone parent families are headed by women.
- Nine out of ten lone parents are women.

column7:
'>lone
adjective
/ləʊn/|a person who prefers to be alone
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

'>interject
verb
/ˌɪntərˈdʒekt/|(+ speech) to interrupt what somebody is saying with your opinion or a remark
column8:
'>Examples:
- ‘You're wrong,’ interjected Susan.

column7:
'>deadpan
adjective
/ˈdedpæn/|without any expression or emotion
column8: often pretending to be serious when you are joking
column9:
'>Examples:
- deadpan humour
- She looked up, completely deadpan.

column7:
'>overture
noun
/ˈəʊvərtʃər/|a piece of music written as an introduction to an opera or a ballet
column8:
'>Examples:
- Prokofiev’s overture to ‘Romeo and Juliet’

column7:

noun
/ˈəʊvərtʃər/|(overture (to somebody)) a suggestion or an action by which somebody tries to make friends, start a business relationship, have discussions, etc. with somebody else
column8:
'>Examples:
- He began making overtures to a number of merchant banks.
- Maggie was never one to reject a friendly overture.

column7:
'>boorish
adjective
/ˈbʊrɪʃ/|very unpleasant and rude
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

'>dismissive
adjective
/dɪsˈmɪsɪv/|(dismissive (of somebody/something)) showing that you do not believe a person or thing to be important or worth considering
column8:
'>Examples:
- a dismissive gesture/tone
- She was always dismissive of other women in the office.
- Other critics were equally dismissive.
- She was very dismissive of his achievements.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|an area of land in the country used for growing crops or keeping animals in, usually surrounded by a fence, etc.
column8:
'>Examples:
- We had to walk across a ploughed field.
- (in a field) We camped in a field near the village.
- People were working in the fields.
- (field of something) We saw golden fields of wheat.
- He planted a field of beans.
- a rice/wheat field
- The house overlooks the sugar cane fields.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|an area of land used for the purpose mentioned
column8:
'>Examples:
- a landing field

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|a large area of land covered with the thing mentioned
column8: an area from which the thing mentioned is obtained
column9:
'>Examples:
- The territory is covered with snow, bare rock and ice fields.
- Prisoners were sent to work in the gas fields in the north.
- the discovery of the oil and gas fields in the North Sea

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|an area of land used for playing a sport on
column8:
'>Examples:
- a football/soccer/sports field
- a baseball/cricket/rugby field
- (on/off the field) Every player on the field did their best today.
- Players need discipline both on and off the field (= when they are playing and also in their free time).
- There was huge excitement as the teams came onto the field.
- Today they take the field (= go on to the field to play a game) against county champions Essex.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|the team that is trying to catch the ball rather than hit it
column8:
'>Examples:
- He took the ball early and hit it through a gap in the field.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|all the people or animals competing in a particular sports event
column8:
'>Examples:
- The strong field includes three world record holders.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|an area of land where a battle is fought
column8:
'>Examples:
- (in the field) a medal for bravery in the field
- (on the field) to die on the field of battle
- a field ambulance/kitchen

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|a particular subject or activity that somebody works in or is interested in
column8:
'>Examples:
- Child development is such an interesting field.
- Genetic science has developed dramatically since I entered the field 40 years ago.
- (in a field) All of them are experts in their chosen field.
- He was awarded a Nobel Prize for his work in this field.
- (in the field of something) She works in the field of adult education.
- I enjoy meeting people in other fields of business.
- (field of something) This discovery has opened up a whole new field of study.
- ‘How big was the bomb, if it did all that damage?’ ‘I don’t know. Not my field’ (= that is not one of the subjects I know about).

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|the fact of people doing practical work or study, rather than working in a library or laboratory
column8:
'>Examples:
- a field study/experiment
- field recordings/observations
- Her findings were based on extensive field and laboratory work.
- We then tested the questionnaire in field conditions.
- (in the field) tests carried out in the field

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|all the people or products competing in a particular area of business
column8:
'>Examples:
- They lead the field in home entertainment systems.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|an area within which the force mentioned has an effect
column8:
'>Examples:
- the earth’s gravitational field
- an electromagnetic field
- Weak electric fields are emitted by all living organisms.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|part of a record that is a separate item of data
column8:
'>Examples:
- You will need to create separate fields for first name, surname and address.
- the use of keys to move between fields

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|to enable somebody to be successful in a particular area of activity because other people or groups have given up competing with them
column8:
'>Examples:
- The complete disarray of the opposition parties leaves the field clear for the government to implement urgent reforms.

column7:
'>field
noun
/fiːld/|to have sexual relationships with a lot of different people
column8:
'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

column7:
'>field
verb
/fiːld/|(field somebody/something) to provide a candidate, speaker, team, etc. to represent you in an election, a competition, etc.
column8:
'>Examples:
- Each of the main parties fielded more than 300 candidates.
- England fielded a young side in the World Cup.

column7:
'>field
verb
/fiːld/|to be the person or the team that catches the ball and throws it back after somebody has hit it
column8:
'>Examples:
- He won the toss and chose to field first.

column7:
'>field
verb
/fiːld/|(field something) to catch the ball and throw it back
column8:
'>Examples:
- He fielded the ball expertly.

column7:
'>field
verb
/fiːld/|(field something) to receive and deal with questions or comments
column8:
'>Examples:
- The BBC had to field more than 300 phone calls after last night's programme.

column7:
'>interminable
adjective
/ɪnˈtɜːrmɪnəbl/|lasting a very long time and therefore boring or annoying
column8:
'>Examples:
- an interminable speech/wait/discussion
- The drive seemed interminable.

column7:
'>omen
noun
/ˈəʊmən/|a sign of what is going to happen in the future
column8:
'>Examples:
- a good/bad omen
- an omen of death/disaster
- (omen for something) The omens for their future success are not good.

column7:
'>sheepish
adjective
/ˈʃiːpɪʃ/|looking or feeling embarrassed because you have done something silly or wrong
column8:
'>Examples:
- Mary gave her a sheepish grin.
- He came into the room looking distinctly sheepish.
- They were obviously a little bit sheepish about the misunderstanding.

column7:
'>sheepishly
adverb
/ˈʃiːpɪʃli/|in a way that shows that you are embarrassed because you have done something silly or wrong
column8:
'>Examples:
- He smiled sheepishly.

column7:
'>rueful
adjective
/ˈruːfl/|feeling or showing that you are sad or sorry
column8:
'>Examples:
- a rueful smile

'>cauterize
verb
/ˈkɔːtəraɪz/|(cauterize something) to burn a wound, using a chemical or heat, in order to stop the loss of blood or to prevent infection
column8:
'>Examples:
- The wound needs to be cauterized.

column7:
'>hangdog
adjective
/ˈhæŋdɔːɡ/|if a person has a hangdog look, they look sad or ashamed
column8:
'>Examples:
- his hangdog expression

column7:
'>par
noun
/pɑːr/|the number of shots a good player should need to complete a course or to hit the ball into a particular hole
column8:
'>Examples:
- a par five hole
- Par for the course is 72.
- (over/under par) She went round the course in three under (= three strokes less than) par.

column7:
'>par
noun
/pɑːr/|the value that a share in a company had originally
column8:
'>Examples:
- (at par) to be redeemed at par
- (above/below par) The company's bonds are trading well above par.

column7:
'>par
noun
/pɑːr/|less well, good, etc. than is usual or expected
column8:
'>Examples:
- I may take tomorrow off if I’m still feeling under par.
- Teaching in some subjects has been well below par.
- I feel slightly below par today.

column7:
'>par
noun
/pɑːr/|to be just what you would expect to happen or expect somebody to do in a particular situation
column8:
'>Examples:
- Starting early and working long hours is par for the course in this job.

column7:
'>par
noun
/pɑːr/|as good, bad, important, etc. as somebody/something else
column8:
'>Examples:
- This place is on a par with the best French restaurants.

column7:
'>par
noun
/pɑːr/|as good as usual or as good as it should be
column8:
'>Examples:
- I didn’t think her performance was up to par.
- Your work is not up to par.

column7:
'>par

/pɑːr/|(in writing) paragraph
column8:
'>Examples:
- See par. 3.

'>duck
noun
/dʌk/|a common bird that lives on or near water and has short legs, webbed feet (= feet with thin pieces of skin between the toes) and a wide beak. There are many types of duck, some of which are kept for their meat or eggs.

- wild ducks

'>duck

'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

'>duck
noun
/dʌk/|meat from a duck
column8:
'>Examples:
- roast duck with orange sauce

- In a large saucepan, melt the duck fat.

column7:
'>duck
noun
/dʌk/|a friendly way of speaking to somebody
column8:
'>Examples:
- Anything else, duck?

column7:
'>duck
noun
/dʌk/|a batsman's score of zero
column8:
'>Examples:

column7:
'>duck
noun
/dʌk/|a plan, an event, etc. that has failed or is certain to fail and that is therefore not worth discussing

'>Examples:
- NO_EXAMPLES

'>duck
noun
/dʌk/|to have made all the preparations needed to do something
column8: to be well organized
column9:
'>Examples:
- The company has its ducks in a row for a move into the Asian market.
- Get your ducks in a row before you retire.

column7:

/səˈkʌm/|to not be able to fight an attack, a temptation, etc.

'>Examples:

- They were all offered bribes and some of them succumbed.
- (succumb to something) He finally succumbed to Lucy's charms and agreed to her request.

- people who succumb easily to exploitation

column7:

/səˈkʌm/|(succumb (to something)) to die from the effect of a disease or an injury
column8:

column7:

column8: the fact of having been found guilty

'>Examples:

column7:

column8:

column7:
'>conviction

column8:

- ‘Not true!’ she said with conviction.
- He said he agreed but his voice lacked conviction.
- The leader's speech in defence of the policy didn't carry much conviction.

column7:
'>stake
noun
/steɪk/|(stake in something) a part or share in a business, plan, etc. that will bring you money or other benefits if it succeeds
column8:
'>Examples:
- She has a personal stake in the success of the play.
- Many young people no longer feel they have a stake in society.
- He has a personal stake in the outcome of the war.

column7:
'>stake
noun
/steɪk/|something that you risk losing, especially money, when you try to predict the result of a race, game, etc., or when you are involved in an activity that can succeed or fail
column8:
'>Examples:
- How much was the stake (= how much did you bet)?
- They were playing cards for high stakes (= a lot of money).
- With only two points separating the top five players, the stakes are high as they enter the final round.

column7:
'>stake
noun
/steɪk/|a wooden or metal post that is pointed at one end and pushed into the ground in order to support something, mark a particular place, etc.
column8:
'>Examples:
- Tall plants can be secured by tying them to stakes.

column7:
'>stake
noun
/steɪk/|a wooden post that somebody could be tied to in former times before being burnt to death (= killed by fire) as a punishment
column8:
'>Examples:
- Joan of Arc was burnt at the stake.

- The prize at stake is a place in the final.

column7:
'>stake

column8:

column7:
'>stake

/steɪk/|used to say how much of a particular quality a person has, as if they were in a competition in which some people are more successful than others

column7:

column7:
'>stake

/steɪk/|(stake something (on something)) to risk money or something important on the result of something
column8:
'>Examples:
- He staked £25 on the favourite (= for example, in horse racing).
- She staked her political career on tax reform, and lost.
- That's him over there—I'd stake my life on it (= I am completely confident).

column7:
'>stake

/steɪk/|(stake something (up)) to support something with a stake
column8:

column7:
